submits the executable for the given label as a
job. This function removes the need for a
helper invoked through
in order to install a
property list. If the job is already installed, this methods returns
In order to use this function, the app must meet the following requirements:
Xcode must sign both the calling app and target executable tool.
The calling app’s
must include an

dictionary of strings. Each string is a textual representation of a code signing requirement the system uses to determine whether the app owns the privileged tool once installed (for example, in order for subsequent versions to update the installed version).
Each key of
is a reverse-DNS label for the helper tool that must be globally unique.
The helper tool must have an embedded
containing an
array of strings. Each string is a textual representation of a code signing requirement describing a client allowed to add and remove the tool.
The helper tool must have an embedded launchd property list. The only required key in this property list is the
key. When the Service Management framework extracts the
property list and writes it to disk, it sets the key for

to an array of 1 element that points to a standard location. You can’t specify your own program arguments, so don’t rely on the system passing custom command line arguments to your tool. Pass any parameters through an inter-process communication (IPC) channel.
The helper tool must reside in the Contents/Library/LaunchServices directory inside the application bundle, and its name must be its launchd job label. So if your launchd job label is
, this must be the name of the tool in your application bundle.

abstract.text: The Service Management clients authorized to add and remove tools.
The Service Management tools owned by the app.
A reference to a CFError object.
Runs an executable tool with root privileges.
A false value.
A true value.
Manage startup items, launch agents, and launch daemons from within an app.
An object the framework uses to control helper executables that live inside an app’s main bundle.
Submits the executable for the given label as a job to
Constants that describe the ability to authorize helper executables or modify daemon applications.
The system-level launch domain.
The authorization rights key for approving and installing a privileged helper tool.
Property list keys that describe the kinds of applications, daemons, and helper executables the framework manages.
A pointer to an opaque authorization reference structure.
A reference to a CFError object.
A reference to a CFString object.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
A type for propagating an unmanaged object reference.
